The capacity decreased greatly during the first ten cycles and leveled off gradually, finally reaching 230.3 mAhÂ·g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 2500 cycles, signifying robust cycling stability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0125"><span>As well known, the high-rate performance of electrode materials in the continuous charge/discharge process is affected by their potential <a href="/topics/engineering/pseudocapacitance" title="Learn more about pseudo capacitance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pseudo capacitance</a> behaviour </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. To further explore the sodium storage kinetics of HBC/VGSs, CV tests were carried out at various sweep rates ranging from 0.2 to 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> in the voltage window of 0.01â€“3.0&nbsp;V (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a). Quantitatively, the percentage of capacitive contribution at the fixed voltage could be quantitatively calculated through the equation of <em>i</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;<em>k</em><sub>1</sub><em>v</em>&nbsp;+&nbsp;<em>k</em><sub>2</sub><em>v</em><sup>0.5</sup>, where <em>k</em><sub>1</sub><em>v</em> and <em>k</em><sub>2</sub><em>v</em><sup>0.5</sup> represent the pseudocapacitive and ionic diffusion contributions, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>. In the range of scanning rate from 0.2 to 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the capacitive contribution gradually increases, which implies multiplicative capacities of the fast Na<sup>+</sup> interaction/extraction process (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><span>b). It can be attributed to the large specific surface area of HBC/ VGS, as well as the hollow bowl-shaped <a href="/topics/engineering/porous-structure" title="Learn more about porous structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous structure</a>. Particularly, the high specific surface area provides more active sites as well as shorter ion transport channels for de/sodiation, while the large pore size is favorable to electrolyte penetration and Na</span><sup>+</sup> rapid transfer. These characteristics promote the surface-induced storage performance of Na<sup>+</sup>, accelerating the reaction kinetics <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c, the capacitance contribution ratio of HBC/VGSs is as high as 71.3% at 1.0&nbsp;mV S<sup>-1</sup>, revealing that the electrochemical Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/storage-process" title="Learn more about storage process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">storage process</a> is controlled by capacitance. The capacitance contribution ratio of HBC (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0070" name="bs0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figure S11</span></span></a><span> c) is significantly larger than that of HBC/VGSs. Aside from its superior lattice to <a href="/topics/engineering/amorphous-carbon" title="Learn more about amorphous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous carbon</a>, CVD-grown graphene is free of heteroatomic doping, which limits its pseudocapacitance. Furthermore, the low-layer graphene has good electron and ion transport properties, facilitating the diffusion of Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> and improving the <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> rate performance </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0285" name="bb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>. Therefore, it shows higher diffusion contribution in capacity contribution compared to HBC.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr5.jpg" height="324" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (346KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (346KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. <span><span><a href="/topics/engineering/kinetics-analysis" title="Learn more about Kinetic analyses from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Kinetic analyses</a> of the HBC/VGSs electrode: a) </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves at different scan rates, b) the proportions of capacitive and diffusion contributions at varying scan rates, c) the proportions of capacitive contributions at 1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>, d) GITT curves and e-f) the calculated Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> during the third discharging and charging process.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130"><span>The <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-kinetics" title="Learn more about diffusion kinetics from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion kinetics</a> of Na</span><sup>+</sup> in HSC, HBC, and HBC/VGSs electrodes were further studied by GITT to gain a better understanding of the mechanism underlying the Na<sup>+</sup> storage performance. The electrode discharge-charge curves measured by GITT are presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>e-f compare the Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> values (</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-3-Frame" transform="translate(2972,877)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î”</mi><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mi is="true">s</mi></msub><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î”</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">t</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-4"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Ï€</mi><mi is="true">Ï„</mi></mrow></mfrac><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">n</mi><mi is="true">m</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">m</mi></msub></mrow><mi is="true">s</mi></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î”</mi><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mi is="true">s</mi></msub><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î”</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">t</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></script></span> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0290" name="bb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0295" name="bb0295" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[59]</span></span></a><span>. The investigations show that the HBC/VGSs electrode demonstrates the highest diffusion coefficients in the sodiation and desodiation process, implying that it has the fastest diffusion kinetics, due to the good compatibility of the in situ-grown mechanically graphene with the <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-interface" title="Learn more about HBC interface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HBC interface</a>. The well-designed 3D structures can conduct electrons rapidly, and the spatially separating active sites for ion transfer.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">After an in-depth investigation of the electrochemical and kinetic properties of HBCs/VGSs, their high-rate performance and stable cycling performance are originated from the following three factors: i) The in-situ vertically grown graphene has robust interfacial contact with the HBC substrate which can accelerate <a href="/topics/materials-science/electron-transfer" title="Learn more about electron transport from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron transport</a> and spatially separate active sites, facilitating the efficient reaction. ii) The subtle bowl-like inner cavity of HBC/VGSs simultaneously mitigates the mechanical stresses caused by volume changes during cycling and increases the tap density. iii) The abundant mesoporous structures in HBC/VGSs are readily available for electrolyte penetration and provide more active sites for sodium storage, consequently improving the Na storage capacity of.</div></section><section id="s0055"><h2 id="st075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140"><span>In summary, we rationally designed and constructed a hollow bowl-shaped porous carbon material with high specific surface areas and three-dimensional structures modified by vertically grown graphene as a high-performance anode for SIBs. The three-dimensional structure formed by the connection of highly conductive graphene not only improves the <a href="/topics/engineering/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a> but also shortens the ion/electron transfer pathway and promotes ion/electron transfer, thus significantly improving the rate performance. In addition, the rich mesoporous structure facilitates the penetration of electrolytes and provides more active sites for sodium storage, and reduces the mechanical stress caused by volume expansion during sodium embedding. Based on these advantages, HBC/VGSs exhibit better electrochemical performance compared with the reported carbon-based materials </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>. The HBC/VGSs electrodes demonstrate a high reversible capacity of 409 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 100 cycles at 0.2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> with an high rate capability (301.6 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 5 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) and good cycling stability (230.3 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span> after 2500 cycles at a <a href="/topics/engineering/high-current-density" title="Learn more about high current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">high current density</a> of 5 A g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>). Notably, it also opens a feasible in-situ approach for the modification of vertical graphene relying on a cost-effective carbon resource (CH<sub>4</sub>) that may come from CO<sub>2</sub> conversion in the future. These results offer a novel perspective on the design of high-performance carbon-based anodes for SIBs as well as energy conservation and emission reduction.</div><section id="s0060"><h3 id="st080" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145"><strong>Guorui Yang:</strong> Methodology, Formal analysis, Writing â€“ original draft. <strong>Ziyi Zhou:</strong> Software, Writing â€“ original draft. <strong>Xiaofeng Liu:</strong> Investigation, Visualization. <strong>Yue Zhang:</strong> Formal analysis, Validation. <strong>Silan Wang:</strong> Formal analysis, Validation. <strong>Wei Yan:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing. <strong>Shujiang Ding:</strong> Resources, Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Supervision.</div></section></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st085" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of Competing Interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st090" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgments</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155">This work was supported by Nationals Natural Science Foundation of China (51908458, 51978569), Natural Science Foundation of Shannxi Province, China (2020JQ-036), Key projects of Shannxi Province, China (2021GXLH-Z-070). We would like to thank the Instrument Analysis Center of Xi'an Jiaotong University for its assistance in instrument testing.</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="s0070"><h2 id="st100" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. availability</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0005">Data will be made available on request.</div></section></div><div class="Tail"></div><div><section class="bibliography u-font-serif text-s" Zhu</div><div id="ref-id-h0270" class="title text-m">A General Metal-Organic Framework (MOF)-Derived Selenidation Strategy for In Situ Carbon-Encapsulated Metal Selenides as High-Rate Anodes for Na-Ion Batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Ad. Liang</div><div id="ref-id-h0295" class="title text-m">Metal Organic Framework-Templated Synthesis of Bimetallic Selenides with Rich Phase Boundaries for Sodium-Ion Storage and Oxygen Evolution Reaction</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">ACS Nano, 13 (5) (2019), pp. 5635-5645</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><span class="link class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor aria-describedby="ref-id-h0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Metal%20Organic%20Framework-Templated%20Synthesis%20of%20Bimetallic%20Selenides%20with%20Rich%20Phase%20Boundaries%20for%20Sodium-Ion%20Storage%20and%20Oxygen%20Evolution%20Reaction&amp;publication_year=2019&amp;author=G.%20Fang&amp;author=Q.%20Wang&amp;author=J.%20Zhou&amp;author=Y.%20Lei&amp;author=Z.%20Chen&amp;author=Z.%20Wang&amp;author=A.%20Pan&amp;author=S.%20Liang" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (28)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724005514"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Resolution of the reciprocity between radical species from precursor and closed pore formation in hard carbon for sodium storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">The research community has been evincing significant interest in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), chiefly owing to their cost-effectiveness, sustainability, and potential to synergistically augment cutting-edge electrochemical storage devices in a myriad of domains such as grid scale energy storage.[1â€“4]</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0020">Hard carbon (HC) has emerged as a highly promising anode material for sodium ion batteries, drawing tremendous interest in producing this material with low-cost and easily accessible precursors. The determination of the crucial parameters of precursors influencing the formation of key structures, such as closed pores, in the HC is of paramount importance. Considering the potential role of free radicals in the structural evolution of the precursors, we, for the first time, delve into the impact of radical species on the development of closed pores by electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy, with petroleum asphalt as the model system. Our findings reveal that carbon centred radicals, with the <em>g</em> value close to that of the free electron (2.0023), exhibit a propensity to form long-range, well-ordered graphitic structures with lower sodium storage capacity. Conversely, the deliberately incorporated oxygen radicals with the <em>g</em> value over 2.005 require a higher energy for ordering the graphitic structures, leading to the creation of closed pores. As a result, the optimal sample showcases a four-fold increase in plateau capacity for sodium ion storage due to the pore filling process. Our research underscores the pivotal role of employing electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy studying the critical structural evolution of functional carbon materials.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2468023024004346"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">g-C&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;N&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt; confined Sb&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;Se&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; as high-performance anode towards rapid and stable Na-ion storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Surfaces and Interfaces</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Nevertheless, the scarcity of lithium resources and uneven geographical distribution hinder the further development of lithium-ion batteries. For this reason, sodium ionic batteries (SIBs) have attracted much attention as high-capacity and low-cost next-generation secondary batteries [1,2]. Although SIBs and LIBs have similar working principles, traditional graphite anodes with larger radius of Na+ greatly obstruct the reversible insertion/deintercalation process of Na+ [3â€“5].</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara007">Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> is considered a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its abundant reserves, low cost, and high theoretical capacity. Nevertheless, significant volume changes and slow electron transfer kinetics significantly limit its rate capability and cycle stability. In this work, we constructed g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub>-coated Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> nanorods (Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>@g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub>) through the hydrothermal method and subsequent thermal treatment to enhance kinetics and achieve high cycle stability. The coating enhances the structure stability, insertion/extraction reversibility of Na<sup>+</sup>, and electrochemical reaction activity. Benefiting from the unique structure and composition, Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>@g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> (8 wt%) nanorod exhibits excellent rate properties with high desodiation capacities of 376.7, 345.5, 336.1, 322.7, 301.4, and 275.0 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.1, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, and 10 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively. Even at 5 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>@g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> (8 wt%) exhibits high cycle stability with a capacity retention of approximately 86.7% after 600 cycles. Ex-situ XRD and XPS results confirm that the introduction of g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> on the surface of Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> inhibits the volumetric expansion and electrode pulverization of Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>, thereby improving the structural stability of the composite material, resulting in an excellent electrochemical capability of Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>@g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> nanorods. Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>@g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> nanorods show massive potential as an anode material for the next-generation high-performance SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X24006285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Research progress on modification and application of two-dimensional anode materials for sodium ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Energy Storage</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0075">Energy storage in rocking-chair batteries is critically dependent on the ability of the electrodes to accommodate the intercalation and migration of ions. Due to the high content of sodium in the earth â€˜s crust, sodium ion batteries are used as a future alternative product for lithium-ion batteries, but commercial graphite cannot meet the deintercalation of sodium ions and is not suitable for application in sodium ion batteries. Two-dimensional (2D) materials are highly valued in the field of energy storage due to their excellent physicochemical properties, such as unique layered structure and low ion diffusion barrier. This paper mainly reviews the application of 2D materials in sodium-ion batteries anodes in recent years. The modification treatment of 2D materials can break through its own limitations in the field of energy storage. The construction of heterostructures and doping engineering can not only alleviate the stacking problem common to 2D materials, but also increase the ion transport sites. Implementing defect chemistry can enhance the adsorption of sodium ions in 2D materials, thereby enhancing the storage capacity of sodium ions. In addition, driving phase transitions in TMDs can enhance electrode cycling efficiency. The presence of grain boundaries, as an important topology of 2D materials, contributes significantly to the adsorption of sodium ions. The article concludes with a summary of the applications of 2D materials in sodium-ion batteries anodes in recent years and an outlook for future development. The aim of this paper is to illustrate the electrochemical behavior of 2D anode materials in sodium-ion batteries and to provide new ideas for future applications in related fields.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979723020684"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Synthesis of multi-cavity mesoporous carbon nanospheres through solvent-induced self-assembly: Anode material for sodium-ion batteries with long-term cycle stability</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">The unique characteristics of MCS, including excellent accessible surface area, well-ordered porous structure, short diffusion path, and sufficient guest loading, make them superior to previous synthetic carbon materials for use as anodes in SIBs. These materials effectively prevent the agglomeration of active substances while stabilizing the anchoring sites [28], resulting in excellent electrochemical performance when applied to SIBs [29â€“36]. For instance, Peng et al. [37] proposed a simple micellar anisotropic self-assembly strategy to fabricate jellyfish-shaped radial multicompartmental nanostructured mesoporous carbon nano hemispheres at the liquidâ€“liquid interface, achieving a recoverable capacity of 124 mAh gâˆ’1 after cycling at 5 A gâˆ’1 in SIBs half-cells.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-3-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-3" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Mesoporous carbon nanospheres (MCSs) are extensively employed in energy storage applications due to their ordered pore size, large specific surface area (SSA), and abundant active sites, resulting in excellent electrochemical performance for sodium storage. However, challenges persist in achieving precise structural control and stable synthesis reactions for these MCSs. Additionally, employing MCSs with a larger SSA in sodium storage applications can lead to increased side reactions and potential structural instability. To address these issues, we propose a solvent-induced self-assembly method for obtaining high nitrogen-containing multi-cavity MCSs with reduced SSA. The morphology and SSA of the nanospheres can be precisely adjusted by regulating the reaction time. Introducing an amine-phenol bridging structure into the polymer system significantly bolsters the structural and morphological stability of the mesoporous materials. The performance of these novel nanospheres in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) is remarkable, exhibiting excellent sodium storage capability and exceptional ultra-long cycle stability. At a rate of 0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the nanospheres achieved a high reversible capacity of 252 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, and even after 20,000 cycles at 5 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, a specific capacity of 136 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> was retained. In summary, our study presents a novel approach for synthesizing mesoporous carbon materials and offers valuable insights for sodium storage research, opening new possibilities for enhancing energy storage applications.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979723010196"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Controlled growth of Co&lt;inf&gt;9&lt;/inf&gt;S&lt;inf&gt;8&lt;/inf&gt; nanoparticle-embedded carbon nanosheets/carbon nanofibers toward high-performance sodium storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2023, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-4-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-4" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Transition metal sulfides (TMSs) are considered as promising anodes for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to their high theoretical capacity and low cost. However, TMSs suffer from massive volume expansion, slow sodium-ion diffusion kinetics, and poor electrical conductivity, which severely restrict their practical application. Herein, we design self-supporting Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub> nanoparticles embedded carbon nanosheets/carbon nanofibers (Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub>@CNSs/CNFs) as anode materials for SIBs. The electrospun carbon nanofibers (CNFs) provide continuous conductive networks to accelerate the ion and electron diffusion/transport kinetics, while MOFs-derived carbon nanosheets (CNSs) buffer the volume variation of Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub>, consequently improving the cycle stability. Benefitting from the unique design and pseudocapacitive features, Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub>@CNSs/CNFs deliver a stable capacity of 516 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and a reversible capacity of 313 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 1500 cycles at 2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. Note that, it also displays excellent sodium storage performance when assembled into a full cell. The rational design and excellent electrochemical properties endow Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub>@CNSs/CNFs with the potential stepping into commercial SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0925838823016316"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Recovered cobalt-nickel sulfide from spent lithium-ion batteries as an advanced anode material toward sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2023, Journal of Alloys and Compounds</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">However, poor real specific capacity and cycle stability due to low conductivity and severe volume expansion remain significant challenges for TMS [30â€“32]. Constructing a bimetallic transition metal sulfide/carbon composite anode for SIBs has proven to be a feasible strategy that can improve electronic conductivity and structural stability upon cycling [33â€“35]. Therefore, it is expected that the direct conversion of spent NMC-type cathode to bimetallic transition metal sulfide/carbon materials will be a desirable method that not only recovers the metallic elements but also reduces the cost of SIBs anode that meets the need for large-scale energy storage.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-5-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-5" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0035">Explosive growth of the electric vehicle market has led to a substantial accumulation of spent lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), causing significant environmental pollution and the wastage of precious metal resources. Thus, we developed a simple hydrothermal method to convert the spent LiNi<sub>0.8</sub>Co<sub>0.1</sub>Mn<sub>0.1</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NMC-811) cathode into CoNi-MOF. After the subsequent sulfidation process, waxberry-like Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@N-doped carbon composites (Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC), as a bimetallic sulfide solid solution, can be successfully synthesized to serve as high-performance anode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). The waxberry-like structure and strong S-C bonds between the carbon matrix and transition metal sulfides ensure the structural stability of the material during the cycle. Besides, the coexistence of Co and Ni in the bimetallic sulfide solid solution generates abundant lattice defects and modifies the electronic structures that significantly improve the charge transfer ability and Na<sup>+</sup> diffusivity. The as-prepared Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC exhibits a high specific capacity of 622 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, outstanding rate capacity of 370 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 5000&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and good cycling stability (330 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 1500 cycles at 5000&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>). This study presents a promising approach for the recycling of spent LIBs into high-performance anodes for SIBs, thus achieving the transformation of waste into valuable resources.</div></div></div></div></li></ul><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-secondary large-alternative button-alternative-icon-left" href="http://www.scopus.com/scopus/inward/citedby.url?partnerID=10&amp;rel=3.0.0&amp;eid=2-s2.0-85146696306&amp;md5=ced53145468d25e952d1eaae87e46c3" target="_blank" id="citing-articles-view-all-btn"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">View all citing articles on Scopus</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></a></div></div></section></div><a class="anchor abstract-link anchor-primary" href="/science/article/abs/pii/S0021979723001145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View Abstract</span></span></a><div class="Copyright"><span class="copyright-line">Â© 2023 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.</span></div></article><div class="u-display-block-from-md col-lg-6 col-md-8 pad-right u-padding-s-top"><aside class="RelatedContent u-clr-grey8" aria-label="Related content"><section class="RelatedContentPanel u-margin-s-bottom"><header id="recommended-articles-header" class="related-content-panel-header u-margin-s-bottom"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary related-content-panel-toggle is-up button-link-icon-right button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="true" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=recommended-articles:type=close"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text"><h2 class="section-title u-h4"><span class="related-content-panel-title-text">Recommended articles</span></h2></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 class="RelatedContentPanelItem u-display-block"><div class="sub-heading u-padding-xs-bottom"><h3 class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article0-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979723000863" title="SiO2 nanospheres as surfactant and template in aqueous material"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>How colloid nature drives the interactions between actinide and carboxylic surfactant in sol: Towards a mesostructured nanoporous actinide oxide material</span></span></span></a></h3><div class="article-source u-clr-grey6"><div class="source">Journal of Colloid and Interface Science, Volume 637, 2023, pp. 207-215</div></div><div class="authors"><span>Zijie</span> <span>Lu</span>, â€¦, <span>Diane</span> <span>RÃ©biscoul</span></div></div><div class="buttons"><a class="anchor anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979723000991/pdfft?md5=cb9b4cbaada45e7c4bfdf9598cacba68&amp;pid=1-s2.0-S0021979723000991-main.pdf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow" aria-describedby="recommended-articles-article1-title"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 35 32" height="20" class="icon icon-pdf-multicolor"><path d="M7 .362h17.875l6.763 6.1V31.64H6.948V16z" stroke="#000" stroke-width=".703" fill="#fff"></path><path d="M.167 2.592H22.39V9.72H.166z" fill="#da0000"></path><path fill="#fff9f9" d="M5.97 3.638h1.62c1.053 0 1.483.677 1.488 1.564.008.96-.6 1.564-1.492 1.564h-.644v1.66h-.977V3.64m.977.897v1.34h.542c.27 0 .596-.068.596-.673-.002-.6-.32-.667-.596-.667h-.542m3.8.036v2.92h.35c.933 0 1.223-.448 1.228-1.462.008-1.06-.316-1.45-1.23-1.45h-.347m-.977-.94h1.03c1.68 0 2.523.586 2.534 2.39.01 1.688-.607 2.4-2.534 2.4h-1.03V3.64m4.305 0h2.63v.934h-1.657v.894H16.6V6.4h-1.56v2.026h-.97V3.638"></path><path d="M19.462 13.46c.348 4.274-6.59 16.72-8.508 15.792-1.82-.85 1.53-3.317 2.92-4.366-2.864.894-5.394 3.252-3.837 3.93 2.113.895 7.048-9.25 9.41-15.394zM14.32 24.874c4.767-1.526 14.735-2.974 15.152-1.407.824-3.157-13.72-.37-15.153 1.407zm5.28-5.043c2.31 3.237 9.816 7.498 9.788 3.82-.306 2.046-6.66-1.097-8.925-4.164-4.087-5.534-2.39-8.772-1.682-8.732.917.047 1.074 1.307.67 2.442-.173-1.406-.58-2.44-1.224-2.415-1.835.067-1.905 4.46 1.37 9.065z" fill="#f91d0a"></path></svg><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View PDF</span></span></a></div></li><li class="RelatedContentPanelItem u-display-block"><div class="sub-heading u-padding-xs-bottom"><h3 class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article2-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1369800122004383" title="Plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition for fabrication of yolk-shell SnO2@Void@C nanowires, as an efficient carbon coating technique for improving lithium-ion battery performance"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition for fabrication of yolk-shell SnO<sub>2</sub>@Void@C nanowires, as an efficient carbon coating technique for improving lithium-ion battery performance</span></span></span></a></h3><div class="article-source u-clr-grey6"><div class="source">Materials Science in Semiconductor Processing, Volume 149, 2022, Article 106901</div></div><div class="authors"><span>Alireza</span> <span>Habibi</span>, â€¦, <span>Shahnaz</span>       o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>

          SVG: {
            scale: 90,
            linebreaks: { automatic: true }
          }
        });
      </script>
