      <script type="text/javascript">
        window.__PRELOADED_STATE__ = {"abstracts":{"content":[{"$$":[{"$":{"id":"st005"},"#name":"section-title","_":"Graphical abstract"},{"$$":[{"$$":[{"$$":[{"$$":[{"$":{"role":"http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4","xmlns:xlink":true,"id":"lk00030","href":"pii:S0021979723001145/ga1","locator":"ga1"},"#name":"link"}],"$":{"id":"f0030"},"#name":"figure"}],"#name":"display"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"sp0005"},"#name":"simple-para"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"as005"},"#name":"abstract-sec"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"ab005","lang":"en","class":"graphical"},"#name":"abstract"},{"$$":[{"$":{"id":"st010"},"#name":"section-title","_":"Abstract"},{"$$":[{"$$":[{"#name":"__text__","_":"Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are expected to be ideal alternatives to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in the future due to their abundant and low-cost resource advantages. A key challenge in SIBs is the development of anodes capable of insertion/extraction of sodium ions (Na"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"+"},{"#name":"__text__","_":") with large radii. Here, hollow bowl-shaped porous carbon materials are uniformly modified with vertically grown graphene (denoted as HBC/VGSs) demonstrating a large specific surface area and three-dimensional structure, which are employed as a viable high-performance anode for SIBs. HBC/VGSs anodes are highly effective at storing sodium because of their structural features. As a result, the HBC/VGSs electrodes provide a high reversible capacity of 409 mAh g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"âˆ’1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" after 100 cycles at 0.1 A g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"âˆ’1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":", as well as outstanding rate capability (301.6 mAh g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"âˆ’1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" at 5 A g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"âˆ’1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"). Moreover, it also shows extraordinary cycling stability (230.3 mAh g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"âˆ’1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" after 2500 cycles at a high current density of 5 A g"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"âˆ’1"},{"#name":"__text__","_":") that is significantly better than the pristine hollow bowl-shaped porous carbon (HBC). Cyclic Voltammetry (CV) and Galvanostatic Intermittent Titration Technique (GITT) were used to analyze the pseudocapacitance and sodium storage kinetics. It was found that high electrical conductivity and large surface area can improve Na"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"+"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" adsorption and diffusion, enhance the electronic conductivity, and deliver superior capacity and rate. The results, taken as a whole, provide new insight into the creation of long-lasting carbon anodes that deliver optimal performance in SIBs."}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"sp0010"},"#name":"simple-para"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"as010"},"#name":"abstract-sec"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"ab010","lang":"en","class":"author"},"#name":"abstract"}],"floats":[],"footnotes":[],"attachments":[{"attachment-eid":"1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-ga1.jpg","ucs-locator":"https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S0021979723001145/ga1/HIGHRES/image/jpeg/76045ea07edbacbe7f5efaeeec211a7b/ga1.jpg","file-basename":"ga1","abstract-attachment":"true","filename":"ga1.jpg","extension":"jpg","filesize":"20753","pixel-height":"152","pixel-width":"500","attachment-type":"IMAGE-DOWNSAMPLED"},{"attachment-eid":"1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-ga1.sml","ucs-locator":"https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S0021979723001145/ga1/HIGHRES/image/gif/1a0925f0fa652b06436bd0faed2fd767/ga1.sml","file-basename":"ga1","abstract-attachment":"true","filename":"ga1.sml","extension":"sml","filesize":"5489","pixel-height":"67","pixel-width":"219","attachment-type":"IMAGE-THUMBNAIL"},{"attachment-eid":"1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-ga1_lrg.jpg","ucs-locator":"https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S0021979723001145/HIGHRES/image/jpeg/e218616a6f52b3c2545adec844ca328e/ga1_lrg.jpg","file-basename":"ga1","abstract-attachment":"true","filename":"ga1_lrg.jpg","extension":"jpg","filesize":"79843","pixel-height":"404","pixel-width":"1328","attachment-type":"IMAGE-HIGH-RES"}]},"accessbarConfig":{"fallback":false,"id":"accessbar","version":"0.0.1","analytics":{"location":"accessbar","eventName":"ctaImpression"},"label":{},"ariaLabel":{"accessbar":"Download class=\"key-dates-help\"><h3 class=\"u-margin-s-bottom u-h4\">Publication milestones</h3><p class=\"u-margin-m-bottom\">The dates displayed for an article provide information on when various publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. class="popover export-citation-popover" id="export-citation-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-export-citation-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 104 128" height="20" class="icon icon-cited-by-66"><path d="M2 58.78V106h44V64H12v-5.22C12 40.28 29.08 32 46 32V22C20.1 22 2 37.12 2 58.78zM102 32V22c-25.9 0-44 15.12-44 36.78V106h44V64H68v-5.22C68 40.28 85.08 32 102 32z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2023.01.092" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2023.01.092</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S0021979723001145&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author" id="ab010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010"><span>Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are expected to be ideal alternatives to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in the future due to their abundant and low-cost resource advantages. A key challenge in SIBs is the development of anodes capable of insertion/extraction of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a> (Na</span><sup>+</sup><span>) with large radii. Here, hollow bowl-shaped <a href="/topics/materials-science/porous-carbon" title="Learn more about porous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous carbon</a><span> materials are uniformly modified with vertically grown graphene (denoted as HBC/VGSs) demonstrating a large specific surface area and three-dimensional structure, which are employed as a viable high-performance anode for SIBs. HBC/VGSs anodes are highly effective at storing <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> because of their structural features. As a result, the HBC/VGSs electrodes provide a high reversible capacity of 409 mAh g</span></span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 100 cycles at 0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, as well as outstanding rate capability (301.6 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 5 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>). Moreover, it also shows extraordinary cycling stability (230.3 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span> after 2500 cycles at a <a href="/topics/engineering/high-current-density" title="Learn more about high current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">high current density</a> of 5 A g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>) that is significantly better than the pristine hollow bowl-shaped porous carbon (HBC). <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about Cyclic Voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Cyclic Voltammetry</a><span><span> (CV) and Galvanostatic Intermittent Titration Technique (GITT) were used to analyze the <a href="/topics/engineering/pseudocapacitance" title="Learn more about pseudocapacitance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pseudocapacitance</a> and sodium storage kinetics. It was found that </span><a href="/topics/engineering/high-electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about high electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">high electrical conductivity</a> and large surface area can improve Na</span></span><sup>+</sup><span> adsorption and diffusion, enhance the <a href="/topics/engineering/electronic-conductivity" title="Learn more about electronic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic conductivity</a><span>, and deliver superior capacity and rate. The results, taken as a whole, provide new insight into the creation of long-lasting <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-anode" title="Learn more about carbon anodes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon anodes</a><span> that deliver <a href="/topics/engineering/optimal-performance" title="Learn more about optimal performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">optimal performance</a> in SIBs.</span></span></span></div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0005"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-ga1.jpg" height="152" alt=""><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (78KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (78KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979723001200"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979723000656"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>Anode material</span></div><div id="k0010" class="keyword"><span>Sodium storage</span></div><div id="k0015" class="keyword"><span>Carbon</span></div><div id="k0020" class="keyword"><span>Graphene</span></div><div id="k0025" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion battery</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">Electric vehicles (EVs) are increasingly popular among consumers as they reduce the emissions of greenhouse gases, and improve air quality in urban centers <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>. However, as the heart of EVs, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) face challenges due to the scarcity of lithium minerals and the unbalanced distribution of lithium resources, which threaten the sustainability of EVsâ€™ markets <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a><span>. Recent years have seen sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) receiving a great deal of attention as an alternative system to LIBs because of their huge reserves and wide distribution of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> resources </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a><span>. Electrode materials significantly affect the comprehensive <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a><span><span> of SIBs. Presently, the developed layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxides</a> and polyanionic compounds </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode materials</a> can meet the practical application requirements due to their high Initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) and superior rate performance </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a><span>. By contrast, the development of <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a> for commercial applications is lagging which substantially impacts the performance of SIBs </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>. Therefore, finding suitable materials as SIBs anodes is essential for accelerating their industrialization.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015"><span><span>As an important member of the intercalation <a href="/topics/materials-science/materials-class" title="Learn more about type materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">type materials</a>, </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/carbonaceous-material" title="Learn more about carbonaceous materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonaceous materials</a><span> have been extensively studied as anode materials for SIBs due to their high conductivity, large surface area, electrochemical, thermal, and <a href="/topics/engineering/mechanical-stability" title="Learn more about mechanical stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mechanical stability</a>, various structural and chemical modifications, low cost of raw materials, and ease of preparation </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>. Among them, hard carbon (HC) is considered as the most promising commercial anode material compared with the alloy-type <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a> and conversion-type counterparts <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a><span>, because of its abundant reserves, competitive costs, low working potential, and good reversible capacity for <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ion from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion</a> storage (about 250â€“300 mAh g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>. However, the large radius of Na<sup>+</sup><span><span> results in slow ion <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-kinetics" title="Learn more about diffusion kinetics from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion kinetics</a> and large volume changes during </span><a href="/topics/engineering/electrochemical-process" title="Learn more about electrochemical processes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical processes</a><span>, which may limit the practical application of <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-anode" title="Learn more about HC anodes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC anodes</a> </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>. Therefore, it remains a great challenge to design suitable HC for SIBs anodes.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020"><span>Currently, a common and effective strategy for addressing the above-mentioned issues is to rationally design and synthesize hollow porous <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbon-nanostructure" title="Learn more about carbon nanostructures from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon nanostructures</a><span> with stable structures, large specific surface areas, and high <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a>, which provide more active sites and accommodate the volume change </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>. Unfortunately, the hollow structures tend to reduce the tap density due to the immoderate inner cavities, while the conductive components are hard to uniformly contact with the active materials <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025"><span><span><span>Herein, we design HBC/VGSs as a high-performance anode for SIBs, which demonstrate uniform three-dimensional (3D) structures, large specific surface areas as well as <a href="/topics/engineering/high-electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about high electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">high electrical conductivity</a>. Notably, HBC/VGSs possess abundant mesoporous structures and unique bowl-type cavities, combining the advantages of hollow and </span><a href="/topics/engineering/porous-structure" title="Learn more about porous structures from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous structures</a><span>. It enables them to reduce the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-strain" title="Learn more about structural strain from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural strain</a> caused by volume expansion, and thereby maintaining </span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a><span> during the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> without sacrificing the tap density. Moreover, the in-situ vertically grown graphene that was uniformly and robustly inlaid on the surface of HBC contacted each other to form an interconnected 3D structure, which facilitates the ion/electron transfer. The obtained HBC/VGSs anodes exhibited a high reversible specific capacity of 409 mAh g</span></span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 100 cycles at 0.2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and rate performance of 301.6 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 5 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, as well as outstanding cycling stability of 230.3 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 5A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 2500 cycles. This work provides new insights into the rational design of highly conductive three-dimensional structures with controllable cavities and advances the development of carbon-based materials as high-performance anode materials for SIBs.</div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030"><span>All chemicals were analytical grade and used as received without further purification. <a href="/topics/materials-science/tetraethyl-orthosilicate" title="Learn more about Tetraethyl orthosilicate from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Tetraethyl orthosilicate</a> (TEOS, AR, 98%) and </span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/hydrofluoric-acid" title="Learn more about Hydrofluoric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Hydrofluoric acid</a><span> (HF, AR 40%) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin <a href="/topics/engineering/biochemicals" title="Learn more about Biochemical from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Biochemical</a> Co., Ltd. Resorcinol (AR, 99%) was supplied by Beijing J&amp;K Scientific Co. Ethylenediamine (EDA, AR, 99%) and Formaldehyde aqueous solution (37â€“40%) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation.</span></div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Preparation of electrode material</h3><section id="s0025"><h4 id="st045" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2.1. Synthesis of hollow sphere carbon (HSC)</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035">68&nbsp;mL ethanol and 80&nbsp;mL <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/deionized-water" title="Learn more about deionized water from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">deionized water</a> were mixed and stirred for 30&nbsp;s in a 250&nbsp;mL conical flask. Then, 3&nbsp;mL TEOS was added into the above mixture and stirred for 30&nbsp;s, and 0.6&nbsp;mL EDA was added and stirred for 20&nbsp;min at room temperature. After that, the conical flask was placed on the oil bath stirrer and 0.4&nbsp;g resorcinol was added for stirring reaction at 30â„ƒ for 5&nbsp;min. Then, 0.6&nbsp;mL formaldehyde aqueous solution (37â€“40%) was added to react for 24&nbsp;h. The resulting product was centrifugally collected, washed several times with ethanol, and dried under vacuum at 60&nbsp;Â°C overnight.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040"><span>After drying, the samples were ground into powder and placed in a <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/corundum" title="Learn more about corundum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">corundum</a> boat, which was heated to 800â„ƒ for 4&nbsp;h in a tubular furnace at 2 â„ƒÂ·min</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> under N<sub>2</sub> conditions. After cooling to room temperature, the black samples were etched with 10% HF for 24&nbsp;h. Following the etching process, the samples were washed several times with deionized water, and HSC was obtained.</div></section><section id="s0030"><h4 id="st050" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2.2. Synthesis of HBC</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045">HBC was synthesized similarly with HSC, except that the dosages of TEOS (3&nbsp;mL) and resorcinol (0.4&nbsp;g) were changed, while other conditions remain the same.</div></section><section id="s0035"><h4 id="st055" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2.3. Synthesis of HBC/VGSs</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050">Initially, a certain mass of ground HBC material was spread in a corundum boat. Then, it was placed in a tubular furnace and heated to 1200â„ƒ in an atmosphere of argon at 5 â„ƒÂ·min<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. Upon the temperature reaching 1200â„ƒ, the argon was closed, and CH<sub>4</sub> and H<sub>2</sub> were introduced simultaneously. The flow rates of CH<sub>4</sub> and H<sub>2</sub> were set at 6&nbsp;mL&nbsp;min<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 160&nbsp;mL&nbsp;min<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively. Then, the temperature was maintained at 1200â„ƒ for 6&nbsp;h. When the temperature began to drop, CH<sub>4</sub> and H<sub>2</sub> were closed and argon gas was turned on. After the tube furnace was cooled to room temperature, the HBC/VGSs composite material was successfully prepared.</div></section></section><section id="s0040"><h3 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Materials characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055"><span><span>The acquired electrode materials were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, XRD-6100), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM, GeminiSEM 500), and <a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about Transmission Electron Microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Transmission Electron Microscopy</a> (TEM, Talos F200X). X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) test was applied using the ESCALAB Xi+ (Thermo Fisher Scientific. U.S.) to analyze the element states. </span><a href="/topics/engineering/raman-spectrum" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a><span> were recorded with a <a href="/topics/engineering/renishaw" title="Learn more about Renishaw from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Renishaw</a> (inVia Qontor) high-resolution spectrometer. The N</span></span><sub>2</sub><span> adsorption-desorption isotherms by using a gas <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/sorption" title="Learn more about sorption from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sorption</a> analyzer (ASAP 2020 instrument, Micromeritics Corporation. U.S.).</span></div></section><section id="s0045"><h3 id="st065" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060"><span>The active material, acetylene black, <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vinylidene" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene</a> difluoride (PVDF) (mass ratio of 7: 2: 1) were mixed and ground uniformly with an appropriate amount of </span><em>N</em>-Methylpyrrolidone (NMP) to prepare the working electrode. The 2032-type coin cells were assembled in a glovebox filled with argon and the content of water and oxygen in the glovebox were less than 0.1&nbsp;ppm, using metallic sodium as the counter electrode, 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub><span><span> in <a href="/topics/engineering/ethylene-carbonate" title="Learn more about Ethylene carbonate from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Ethylene carbonate</a> (EC): Dimethyl carbonate (DMC): Ethyl Methyl Carbonate (EMC)&nbsp;=&nbsp;1:1:1&nbsp;vol% with 2.0% Fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) as the electrolyte for SIBs. The </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a><span> of the samples was measured on the LAND CT2001A multi-channel <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> testing system, with a voltage range of 0.01â€“3.0&nbsp;V </span></span><em>vs.</em> Na<sup>+</sup><span>/Na. CHI 660e ï¼ˆChenHuaï¼‰ electrochemical workstation was used to conduct the Cyclic Voltammetry (CV) and <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a><span> (EIS) tests. GITT measurements were performed on the experimental electrode after the <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about SEI from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEI</a> film was formed by activation at 0.1 A g</span></span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> current density for the first cycle, and hold 10&nbsp;min for discharge/charge state with a relaxation interval of 40&nbsp;min to test.</div></section></section><section id="s0050"><h2 id="st070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065">The preparation process for HBC/VGSs is schematically illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>. Firstly, tetraethyl orthosilicate and ethylenediamine were mixed in <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/deionized-water" title="Learn more about deionized water from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">deionized water</a> to form SiO</span><sub>2</sub> sphere templates. In the following step, polybenzoxazine (PB) was produced by polymerizing formaldehyde and resorcinol with ethylenediamine. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>a, the SEM image shows that SiO<sub>2</sub>@PB/SiO<sub>2</sub> has an average diameter of approximately 200&nbsp;nm with favorable dispersion and uniformity. TEM images (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>b) further indicate that each SiO<sub>2</sub>@PB/SiO<sub>2</sub> sphere has a core-hell structure, indicating a uniform coating of PB on SiO<sub>2</sub><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/nanosphere" title="Learn more about nanospheres from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanospheres</a>. Then, SiO</span><sub>2</sub><span><span>@C composite <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nanosphere" title="Learn more about nanospheres from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanospheres</a> were prepared after </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/calcination" title="Learn more about calcination from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">calcination</a>. As HF etching was used to remove the SiO</span><sub>2</sub><span> templates, the carbon shell collapsed into its internal cavity, forming a hollow porous bowl-like structure. In the end, HBC/VGS are obtained by growing graphene uniformly on the surface of the HBC under a mixed gas atmosphere of hydrogen and methane by the <a href="/topics/engineering/chemical-vapor-deposition" title="Learn more about chemical vapor deposition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">chemical vapor deposition</a> (CVD) method.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr1.jpg" height="240" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (124KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (124KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0015"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <span>Schematic diagram of synthesizing HSC, <a href="/topics/materials-science/porous-carbon" title="Learn more about HBC from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HBC</a> (HBC is synthesized in the same way as HSC, except that the dosage of </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/tetraethyl-orthosilicate" title="Learn more about TEOS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEOS</a> and resorcinol are changed, and other conditions remain unchanged.) and HBC/VGSs.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0070">As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a and d, the average diameter of the as-prepared HSC is about 200&nbsp;nm, which is hollow and porous. The SEM images (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a><span>a-b) display that HBC has a uniform bowl-like structure with a size of about 200&nbsp;nm which resembling a completely deflated volleyball. Through the <a href="/topics/engineering/carbonization-process" title="Learn more about carbonization process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonization process</a> and the elimination of SiO</span><sub>2</sub>, the surface of HBC became rough, allowing plenty of pores to form. Furthermore, HBC tend to stack on each other, increasing the packing density compared to hollow spheres (such as HSC). It can be seen from the TEM images in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>e and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a><span>c-d, the obtained HBC has a homogeneous hollow structure, and the wall thickness of the bowl is measured at about 30&nbsp;nm. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image and the selected area <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a> (SAED) patterns were displayed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a><span>e-f respectively, which reflects that the hollow bowl-like carbon was <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-material" title="Learn more about amorphous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous</a>. The element mapping images (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>g) further illustrate the distribution of C and N elements in the sample HBC.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr2.jpg" height="649" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (775KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (775KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>Morphology and chemical composition characterization. SEM and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a> images of a, d) HSC, b, e) </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/porous-carbon" title="Learn more about HBC from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HBC</a><span><span>, c, f, g) HBC/VGSs. h) HRTEM image of HBC/VGSs. i) is the lattice fringes of VGSs magnified in figure h. The inset shows the average interspaces of VGSs calculated by <a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a> diffraction fringe. j) The dark-field TEM image of HBC/VGSs and corresponding </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDS</a> mapping of C and N.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075">As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span><span>c, vertical graphene <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanosheet" title="Learn more about nanosheets from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanosheets</a> grew uniformly on the surface of HBC that still maintained a bowl-like structure, inferring its robust thermal stability. Vertical </span><a href="/topics/engineering/graphene-sheet" title="Learn more about graphene sheets from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphene sheets</a> grew continuously and radially perpendicular to the surface of HBC, generating a sophisticated 3D structure. As displayed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>f-g, the brighter area belongs to the vertical graphene growth region that mainly covers the edge of HBC, while the darker area is the amorphous HBC carbon material region. HRTEM images (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>h-i) demonstrate graphitized lattice fringes, confirming the successful preparation of HBC/VGSs. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>i displays a dilated <a href="/topics/engineering/layer-graphene" title="Learn more about graphene layer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphene layer</a><span> spacing of â‰ˆ0.346&nbsp;nm greater than the <a href="/topics/engineering/interlayer-distance" title="Learn more about interlayer distance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">interlayer distance</a> (0.3354&nbsp;nm) of graphite.</span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">plane (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;<span>2). The high-angle annular dark field (HAADF) TEM image and <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDS</a> elemental mappings of the HBC/VGSs are manifested in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>j, demonstrating the <a href="/topics/engineering/homogeneous-distribution" title="Learn more about homogeneous distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">homogeneous distribution</a> of C and N elements.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0085">The XRD patterns of HSC, HBC, and HBC/VGSs in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a show highly broadened (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;<span>2) <a href="/topics/engineering/bragg-cell" title="Learn more about Bragg from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Bragg</a> peaks. Due to the graphene modification, the (0</span>&nbsp;0&nbsp;2) peak of HBC/VGSs is sharper and shifts to a higher 2Î¸ value of 25.3Â° compared to that of HSC and HBC. The calculated VGSs mean layer spacing is 0.35&nbsp;nm, agreeing well with the result of HRTEM. Raman spectra for HSC, HBC, and HBC/VGSs are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b. In terms of carbon materials, the defect and disordered induced <span class="small-caps">D</span>-band that centers at 1345&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup> is associated with the breathing pattern of sp<sup>2</sup><span> carbon atoms in the <a href="/topics/engineering/aromatic-ring" title="Learn more about aromatic rings from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aromatic rings</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>. The graphitic G-band located at 1580&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup> is derived from the conjugated structure in chains or rings of sp<sup>2</sup> carbon <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a><span> The defect and <a href="/topics/engineering/graphitization" title="Learn more about graphitization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphitization</a> degree of carbon materials can be evaluated by </span><em>I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub></em> integral peak intensity ratio. The values of <em>I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub></em><span> for HSC, HBC, and HBC/VGSs are calculated to be 0.817, 0.961, and 0.964, respectively. This further gives strong evidence that the existence of defects and <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-carbon" title="Learn more about amorphous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous carbon</a> in the HBC/VGSs composite.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr3.jpg" height="432" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (357KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (357KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. <span><span>a, b) <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> patterns and </span><a href="/topics/engineering/raman-spectrum" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> of HSC, HBC, HBC/VGSs, respectively. c) </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a><span> survey spectrum of the HSC, HBC, and HBC/VGSs. d) High-resolution C 1s <a href="/topics/engineering/ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> spectra of HBC/VGSs.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090">To elucidate the surface chemical properties of HSC, HBC, and HBC/VGSs samples, XPS analysis was carried out and the result is displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0070" name="bs0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figure S3</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c, d. The survey XPS spectrum presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c possesses three typical peaks, indicating the coexistence of C, N, and O atoms. However, the characteristic peak of N is absent from the survey spectrum of HBC/VGSs, which is attributed to the volatilization of N atoms allocating on the surface as a result of the high-temperatures treatment. The high-resolution XPS spectrum of C 1s in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d exhibits three peaks at 284.5, 285.2, and 288.7&nbsp;eV, corresponding to C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C/C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C, C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O/C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">N/C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C, and COOH bonds, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>. As illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>a-I, multiple N<sub>2</sub><span><span> adsorption experiments were conducted to determine the specific surface area and <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-structure" title="Learn more about pore structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore structure</a> of the samples. The specific surface area, Pore </span><a href="/topics/engineering/diameter-distribution" title="Learn more about diameter distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diameter distribution</a>, and corresponding error analysis of HSC, HBC, and HBC/VGSs are summarized in Table S1 and </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0070" name="bs0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figure S5</span></span></a>. It is found that HBC/VGS demonstrates the highest average surface area of 1028&nbsp;Â±&nbsp;3.3&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, which is higher than HBC (980.3&nbsp;Â±&nbsp;9.9&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) and HSC (500&nbsp;Â±&nbsp;10.3&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>). Notably, compared to HSC and HBC, HBC/VGSs have more abundant porosity with 95.2% of the total pore size mediated by pores, which not only facilitates electrolyte penetration but also effectively shortens the Na<sup>+</sup> transport distance <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a><span>. Furthermore, abundant <a href="/topics/engineering/micropore" title="Learn more about micropores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">micropores</a> in the structure can provide more sodium storage sites and avoid excessive electrolyte decomposition </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr4.jpg" height="523" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (481KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (481KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723001145-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <span>a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves at 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> of HBC/VGSs, b) galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles at different cycles of HBC/VGSs at the current density of 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, c) cycling performance of HSC, HBC and HBC/VGSs at the current density of 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, d) galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles at different cycles of HBC/VGSs at the current density of 0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> â€“5 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, e) rate capability of HBC/VGSs compared with HSC and HBC at various current densities, f) <a href="/topics/engineering/nyquist-plot" title="Learn more about Nyquist plots from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Nyquist plots</a> before and after 100 and 200 cycles, g) long-term cycling performance of HBC/VGSs at 5 A g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095">The electrochemical performance of HSC, HBC, and HBC/VGSs electrodes was evaluated in a half-coin cell using Na metal as counter-electrode. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a displays the CV test of the initial 5 cycles for the HBC/VGSs electrode, which was conducted at a scan rate of 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> within a voltage range from 0.01 to 3.0&nbsp;V and the CV.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100">curves of HSC and HBC are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0070" name="bs0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figure S6</span></span></a><span>a-b. During the first cathodic scan, three distinct irreversible reduction peaks located at 0.92, 0.63, and 0.13&nbsp;V are mainly attributed to the decomposition of the electrolyte on surface the electrode to form a <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte</a> film (SEI) </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>. The subsequent CV curves have a good overlap, underlining the reversibility of the HBC/VGSs electrode. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b demonstrates the galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) profiles of HBC/VGSs electrodes with initial five cycles at a current density of 0.2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>. It was observed that all samples had an unnoticeable voltage platform in the cycle, similar to previously reported porous <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-anode" title="Learn more about HC anodes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC anodes</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105">The cycling performance of HSC, HBC, and HBC/VGSs electrodes at 0.2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> is displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span><span>c. All samples demonstrate acceptable cyclic stability in a short range at <a href="/topics/engineering/low-current-density" title="Learn more about low current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">low current density</a>. However, a continuous </span><a href="/topics/engineering/activation-process" title="Learn more about activation process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">activation process</a> at the beginning of the charging/discharging stage results in a decline in capacity over the first 10 cycles. The reason for this can be attributed to the gradually broadened diffusion channels for ions, the change in microstructure of electrode within the reaction, the increased wetting phenomenon by the electrolyte, as well as the gradual stable interface between electrolyte and electrode.</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a> The ICE of HBC/VGSs is only 32.3%, while HSC and HBC have ICEs of 23.8% and 41.5%, respectively. Nonetheless, after 100 cycles at 0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the HBC/VGSs anode delivers a reversible capacity of 409 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, which is higher than that of HSC (70.9 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>)1 and HBC (337 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0070" name="bs0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figure S7-</span></span></a>9 present the SEM images of HSC, HBC, and HBC/VGSs experiencing 100 cycles at 0.2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. The HBC/VGSs maintained an intact.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110"><span><a href="/topics/engineering/nanomaterial" title="Learn more about nanostructure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanostructure</a>, demonstrating the high </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> and reversibility of the electrode material resulting from the coating of vertically grown graphene.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d exhibits the GCD profiles of the HBC/VGSs electrode at different current densities within the range of 0.1â€“5 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>e compares the rate performance of HSC, HBC, and HBC/VGSs at various current densities. The HBC/VGSs electrode can provide 701.4, 542.2, 462.8, 406.7, 358.7, and 303.2 mAhÂ·g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at different current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2 and 5 AÂ·g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively. When the current density returns from 5 AÂ·g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> to 0.1 AÂ·g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the capacity is reversibly restored to 466.1 mAhÂ·g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. Compared with the previously reported carbon-based materials (Table S2) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a><span>, it shows good rate performance in SIBs. The good rate performance of HBC/VGSs can be attributed to the <a href="/topics/engineering/synergistic-effect" title="Learn more about synergistic effect from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">synergistic effect</a><span> of the hollow bowl-shaped structure and vertically grown graphene. The hollow bowl-shaped structure allows HBC/VGSs to remain stable during cycling without sacrificing the tap density. Vertical graphene enhances the <a href="/topics/engineering/electronic-conductivity" title="Learn more about electronic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic conductivity</a> and improves the ion/electron transport kinetics, resulting in satisfactory rate performance.</span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120"><span><a href="/topics/engineering/nyquist-plot" title="Learn more about Nyquist plots from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Nyquist plots</a> of HBC/VGSs electrode before and after 100th and 200th cycling is displayed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>f. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a><span> plots show that the <a href="/topics/engineering/charge-transfer-resistance" title="Learn more about charge transfer resistance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">charge transfer resistance</a> (R</span></span><sub>ct</sub>) of HBC/VGSs decreased significantly during the charge/discharge cycles. Notably, the R<sub>ct</sub> of the electrode decreases sharply after 100 cycles in the high-frequency field, because the ion/electron conductivity of the electrode increases rapidly during moderate activation. As illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0070" name="bs0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figure S10</span></span></a>, the HBC/VGSs electrode exhibits a lower R<sub>ct</sub> value in comparison with HSC and HBC, indicative of the faster reaction kinetics. Furthermore, the long-term cycling performance was tested at a high rate of 5 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>g). The capacity decreased greatly during the first ten cycles and leveled off gradually, finally reaching 230.3 mAhÂ·g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 2500 cycles, signifying robust cycling stability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0125"><span>As well known, the high-rate performance of electrode materials in the continuous charge/discharge process is affected by their potential <a href="/topics/engineering/pseudocapacitance" title="Learn more about pseudo capacitance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pseudo capacitance</a> behaviour </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. To further explore the sodium storage kinetics of HBC/VGSs, CV tests were carried out at various sweep rates ranging from 0.2 to 1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> in the voltage window of 0.01â€“3.0&nbsp;V (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a).
